history.content:
I actually found the answer rereading the directions if anyone runs into a the same problem. The provided input file contains $$2m$$ values. I was putting all $$2m$$ integers in the input into the Bloom filter but using the $$m$$ value to calculate $$n$$. Obviously this makes $$n$$, the size of the bloom filter too small.

You also don't need to generate random numbers for negatives at that point. You can simply use that last half of the input file.

The office hour transcript also suggests using the median of 10 trials as opposed to the average.

children.subject: It almost sounds like you are an order of magnitude over if you error rate is lower than the theoretic value.
I found my issue, had a bug in my code, was loading the wrong config
@Mike, I am having the same issue. What ended up being the config problem?

If you are using python task 3 passes in a config and your Bloom Filter constructor takes a config parameter. If you are using the default config provided, the config passed in needs to be updated to match your scenario (m, k, n), for me I wasn't calculating n correctly. The lecture explains how to calculate little n from variables we have available.
@Mike, I was so caught up in getting Task 3 working that I lost sight of the relationship between c,m, and n. Thank you...
As a Hypothetical what I am seeing is my theoretical error rate is like .01 and my bf error rate is like .001. Seems like I might be an order of magnitude off?
with some system time functions clock time comes back as a float number of seconds.  you have to multiply it by 1000 to get milliseconds.  that may be the case here

I would like to add something I found when having the same issue.  In my test code, I was using clock time to generate the different seeds for the hash functions.  However, after going back to look, the timer only had a second granularity.  As a result, each hash had a high likelihood of having the same seed.  As a result, the bloom filter had a higher than normal collision rate.

Here is how you compute your actual false positive rate:

1) Add the first $$m$$ elements to your Bloom Filter (100,000 items should be enough for $$m$$)

2) Then use the other 100,000 elements (the input file provided contains 200,000) to test for collisions. 

Since there are no duplicate values in the input file provided, every time your Bloom Filter thinks it contains one of the elements from the second half of the input, you can count it as a collision.

3) Finally, your false positive rate = collisions / 100,000 (collisions divided by the number of withheld elements)

Isn't the false positive rate 

false positives / (false positives + true negatives)

as seen here?

history.content:
I was wondering if anyone else is getting false positive rates significantly higher  than the theoretical values.

Bloom filters seem pretty straight forward. I'm passing task 2. To calculate false positives, I queried the bloom filter with 10000 random integers not in the test input. If the bloom filter query returns true, I add +1. Then the false positive rate is simply the number of false positives / 10000. I average these rates over 10 trials.

Is anyone getting rates close to theoretical? Or does someone see something I'm doing drastically wrong?
history.subject: High False Positive Rate
